The best Final Fantasy game I have ever played, yet it's not my favorite. This is one of the games that made me and easily one of my favorite games ever [/i]even though it is not my favorite Final Fantasy game. The thing I love the most about this game is the endgame. Capturing monsters, fighting superbosses, obtaining celestial weapons (even though some of them are a right pain), maxxing out the sphere grid, the works. It is one of the only times I didn't mind grinding my butt off to be super powerful. But whether or not you go that far with the game, the story is utterly remarkable and a true gem of its time. The characters are all memorable and the villains are all superb! The traditional turn based combat is awesome and I never get bored of hearing that iconic battle theme! There are so many twists and turns throughout the story that you never know how it's gonna end until you get there. It constantly keeps you on the edge of your seat! All of this and more, Final Fantasy X is the last Final Fantasy I ever had tons of fun with with and I can only hope and pray one day we'll get a remake of this beautiful piece of art like Final Fantasy VII did!

[b]Only about [i]Final Fantasy X[/i]:[/b]

This is going to be a [i]pretty lukewarm[/i] recommendation.

Even though the game has aged better than most of its competitors and still manages to offer, to some degree, a captivating and inspiring experience—enough for me to recommend it to young genre enthusiasts trying to get familiar with the classics—I also think that, for the majority of players, nostalgic veterans included, it simply doesn’t have [i]much[/i] to offer nowadays.

Whether in spectacle, narrative, or gameplay, time moved on, and what was once one of the most impressive productions of its era now has [i]nothing[/i] that hasn’t been surpassed by later titles, especially when we look at other genres.

The magic of [i]Final Fantasy[/i] hasn’t been exclusive or novel for at least two decades. Pretending that this is still something [i]indispensable[/i] for JRPG fans would be disingenuous.

It once was—back when the game alone could justify buying a PS2. It isn’t anymore. [i]Simple as that.[/i]

Still, in one way or another, the magic is there. 

It’s still very easy to be transported into its world when the introduction combines a exciting visually well-crafted universe with memorable melodies pushed right to the forefront. It’s [i]pure poetry.[/i]

This sense of aesthetics remains one of the franchise’s most defining traits—an irresistible invitation to a universe overflowing with charm and unforgettable moments. 

[i]Final Fantasy[/i] never failed to pull you into the adventure.

Being such an ambitious production for its time means that even a modest remaster like this still offers a competent presentation. Despite stiff animations, kinda expressionless faces, and awkward scenes typical of games this old, the world overflows with detail everywhere you go: NPC outfits, stylized character models that aged surprisingly well, memorable environments, striking monster designs, and the prerendered indoor dioramas that lend every location a convincing atmosphere. 

It’s a rich and vibrant universe that once showcased enviable technical mastery.

And the FMVs are still excellent!

If there’s something I’ve noticed about the franchise over the years, it’s that they never let common sense or practicality get in the way of something [i]cool[/i]. Maybe that’s why visually the games always look so unique, regardless of how incoherent what you’re seeing might be.

Combat animations and effects are a highlight. They have clarity, impact, and that gratifying snappiness that sells the spectacle without wasting your time with scenes you’ll watch [i]thousands[/i] of times.

Overall, the game has a sense of a cinematic language that, while not extraordinary by today’s standards, was one more step among many the franchise had already taken toward making the player feel like they were watching a [i]playable movie.[/i]

The pacing is excellent, respecting moments of calm while keeping the story moving forward with frequent changes of scenery, well-crafted locations, and occasional gimmicks that keep things fresh.

But unfortunately, all that quality comes with severe writing issues and gameplay limitations inherent to the genre, which are by far what aged the [i]worst[/i] in this package.

Beyond being a melodramatic young-adult story aimed at early-2000s teenagers—full of strong themes, iconic moments, and a kind of innocence and positivity that will [i]never[/i] return—the execution has clear problems. Beneath the pomp, the narrative falters in a [i]very[/i] frustrating way.

This is one of those stories where the script overrides character agency. No matter how forced, incoherent, or contradictory something is, it happens [i]because the script demands it[/i]. The result is a narrative full of loose ends and artificial mysteries, because characters consistently avoid asking obvious questions even when they have every reason—and opportunity—to ask them.

Often, answers are [i]right there[/i], embodied in friendly characters the protagonist interacts with constantly, yet nothing is revealed organically. Scenes end abruptly, characters forget important events, or ignore them outright, only to revisit the matter hours later.

A major example is Tidus—still as insufferable as I remembered—whose agency is repeatedly stifled. His personality is sidelined whenever something crucial to his motivation could be addressed. He avoids asking about [i]anything[/i] in detail, even while surrounded by allies willing to clarify things. 

It’s not avoiding the elephant in the room; it’s acknowledging it in [i]installments[/i], piece by piece, solely because the script dictates it.

Mysteries need a purpose. When the answers are literally one very obvious question away, the whole thing is just stupid and frustrating. It feels like an amateur tactic to hide how shallow the story is. 

The dialogue doesn’t help: aside from a few iconic lines, it’s weak, awkwardly delivered, and written with a sense of humor that wouldn’t land even for a toddler. Many characters are one-note archetypes with little group chemistry, relying on charisma they don’t always have. They are not more than the sum of their parts.

Yuna is the only remotely interesting and developed character for most of the first half. [i]That[/i] says a lot.

The story may have high points and solid pacing, but it’s clear that [i]this[/i] is the element that aged the worst. And it being an major part of the experience, greatly hinders the appreciation of the work.

And about the gameplay… well… it’s as polished as you’d expect—and just as exhausting and repetitive.

The mechanics are straightforward and intuitive, remaining nearly identical to their early variations—only refined to create a smoother, more pleasant flow.

Combat encounters are well crafted, often feeling like small puzzles that encourage you to switch strategies (and characters) constantly. Bosses are equally well made, each with some kind of exclusive gimmick or special mechanic that keeps the fights genuinely fun.

The progression system, in turn, promises customization but becomes a tedious process of filling nodes rather than making meaningful decisions. For more than half of the game, you’ll barely see its real potential and will likely dread upgrading all seven characters. 

I liked the simpler equipment system and how they prevented gear from becoming useless as the game progresses by removing vertical numeric upgrades and replacing them with specific bonuses. This makes carrying different weapons and armor worthwhile instead of selling them, with satisfying payoffs whenever they allows you to squeeze out an advantage.

Unfortunately, this isn’t enough to mask the genre’s inherent repetition or the fact that the combat isn’t truly strategic. Most decisions boil down to elimination and efficiency rather than planning. The game is well balanced but generally easy, meaning you rarely need to explore every mechanic.

With random encounters paced poorly, they eventually feel like [i]jumpscare simulators[/i], draining your patience. Before you reach the halfway point, you’ll have heard the same battle theme [i]thousands[/i] of times.

[i]FFX[/i] starts strong, but soon the interruptions become overwhelming and features like speeding up gameplay or disabling battles become tempting. 

A game that makes me want to avoid a core part of it has, in my view, [i]failed.[/i]

Exploring an area for 40 minutes when it should take 5 without interruptions feels like a joke… but it isn’t.

So... that’s it.

[i]FFX[/i] still has charm and surprising quality even today, but its flaws and limitations are more visible than ever. People have an irrational attachment to the franchise—myself included—but not everything was perfect. Far from it.

To enjoy this, you'll need a lot of time and tolerance, which may very well not be worth it in the end.

[i]Proceed at your own risk.[/i]

First off, the part that makes me thumbs this down: This HD remaster is frankly a bit of a mess. It crashes regularly under all manner of different circumstances, game will occasionally softlock into a black screen when entering a combat encounter, character models have blacked out during cutscenes (which is kinda funny but it kills the gravitas of a scene quite dead), and FMVs will occasionally just green screen, forcing me to reboot the game and endure a whole chunk of gameplay/cutscenes before getting back to the bit I need to see.

While the problems do not impede the totality of the experience from being enjoyable - and of course some of these problems can be fixed with end user tinkering I don't need to be told about this - these are issues that presented themselves across three different devices (one of them the Steam Deck) and feels a little unacceptable for the product out of the box, especially as compared to memories of playing this game on the PS2 where obviously there was no such performance hiccups, and of course some of these crashes can occur at extremely inopportune moments. There are some other issues as well, which may or may not matter to you depending on how much you care about fidelity to the original product - this game could be said to be more of a reconstruction than a remaster of the game since a lot of the original game data was lost by the devs, and so it doesn't quite ***look right***. These are differences that are ultimately minor and won't matter to the vast majority of players unless you played the PS2 original or you care about authenticity with your experience to the highest degree, but if they matter to you they'll matter a lot.

The games themselves? Excellent JRPGs, of course, and I don't feel obliged to elucidate on their qualities and flaws in here given how much has already been written about them - they peak at phenomenal while occasionally cratering to tedious, but overall I wholeheartedly recommend experiencing them if you are a fan of the JRPG genre or the Final Fantasy franchise in specific, but I would not rate this particular port as the must-go method of doing so, even with fixes and mods applied.

TL;DR an acceptable port if you're patient, but hardly ideal.

I'll start by saying I loved playing X as a kid, and the nostalgia potential was too strong not to pick this up on Steam. Unfortunately, while the nostalgia held up, the port did not. X crashed on me quite often on Steam Deck, so I saved frequently. Eventually, I found that I could not enter a particular building to pick up Wakka's celestial weapon without the game crashing every single time. So, I loaded up my cloud save on my PC, entered just fine, and I continued playing on my Steam Deck. Well, eventually the game wouldn't boot and I received notices that something was wrong with the game files. I validated, and no problems were detected. Huh, odd. Not one day later and my Deck's NVMe, the one the game was played on, died. Whether the game was at fault, I cannot say. I can say that my cloud saves were corrupted and I lost all my 70+ hours of progress. So, there's that.

In all, love X to pieces. I just wish the port were more stable on Deck. As for X-2, some people love it. I'm not one of them, but I can see the appeal.

As is well documented in many, MANY threads on the Steam forums, Reddit, etc. (which I unfortunately did not find until after purchasing), this game just does not run well on modern hardware. Most notably (but not the only issue this game has), the pre-rendered cutscenes frequently display with sound but no video, instead just displaying visually as a solid green screen. There are several documented fixes for this issue, but they only sometimes work. In particular, the fixes often stop working after 30-60 minutes of play time, requiring the player to close and restart the game once or twice an hour just to make it work properly. This is doable, but is a pain and quite frankly should not be necessary.

It's not uncommon for games from the early 2000s to require effort on the part of the user in order to make them run well on modern hardware, so in some sense this game is not unique in that regard - but this game is unlike, for example, the original Star Wars: Knights of the Old Republic, in that it takes [i]much[/i] more effort to get this game working and to some extent this one is just never going to run well no matter what you do. I've been through three or four different threads of people discussing the issues with this release and I've tried half a dozen different fixes, and some of them work to some extent but I still need to reboot the game at every save point. This is especially egregious because unlike KotOR (for which the version available on Steam is the original version from 2003), this version of this game is ostensibly a "remaster" and was released in 2013 (2016 for Windows PCs); in some sense, this version is not even an "early 2000s" game!

FFX is an absolute classic, and this abominable release does not do it justice. I've paid for it and so I'll still play it, but I happen to know the versions of this "remaster" on pretty much any other platform do not have the issues of this Steam version. If you want to play this game, do yourself a favor: Buy it on Switch, or on PlayStation, or on literally any other platform.

Couldn’t play Final Fantasy X back in the PS2 days. Twenty years later, I finally jump in with the HD Remaster, thinking I scored a steal. Thirty bucks gets me not just FFX, but also two sequels. Three games for the price of one—sweet deal, right?
Yeah… no. Big mistake.

I’ll be real: I expected to hate FFX. Everyone and their cousin swore that’s when the franchise lost its soul. No world map, no open wandering, just a straight railroad until you get the airship, which is basically just fast travel. 

And yet… the damn thing grew on me. Blitzball? Awesome idea, but let me play it, not just sit there with an RPG inside my RPG. Kimahri? Doesn’t deserve the hate—he’s weird, sure, but Blue Magic being nerfed was the real crime. Tidus? Thought he was a lobotomized manchild at first, but I ended up loving him like everyone else.

The ending? Genuinely gut-punch bittersweet—first time a Final Fantasy ending ever hit me like that. The Sphere Grid? Best innovation in the game. Way better than old-school level ups, to the point I can’t imagine going back. 

Overdrives were mid, though—spamming Quick Attack was more effective than pulling off flashy moves. And once you hit that “break damage limit” wall, it’s just bloated HP numbers and longer, more boring boss fights. Still, the cast worked, the story had weight, and Wakka, Auron, Kimahri, and Rikku carried the whole damn thing. Loved it, flaws and all. Solid 8/10.

Then I made the mistake of booting up X-2.

Oh my god. It’s like they looked at FFX and said: “You know what people loved? Let’s throw all that in the trash and replace it with glitter and grind.” Dresspheres sound cool, but in practice? Snooze. The combat got slower, the grind got dumber, and the story… Jesus. Characters you loved suddenly turned into caricatures. Rikku? Childish. Yuna? Bland. Brother? Full-on clown shoes. 

And the game forces you into minigames so bad they’d be cut from Mario Party. To get the “true” ending, you basically need a PhD in guide-following. And the payoff? Revive Tidus for a Disney Channel happy ending that straight-up ruins what made FFX’s ending great.

And just to put the cherry on this dumpster sundae: the “Defeat Vegnagun” achievement—aka the final boss, the thing everyone has to beat to finish the game? Only 3.3% of players have it.

Three. Point. Freaking. Three.

That means if you actually finish this game, you join an elite club of masochists who willingly crawled through this glitter-coated poopoo show and came out the other side with PTSD and a trophy no one asked for.

So congrats, you’re not just a gamer—you’re a gimp.

First off, the part that makes me thumbs this down: This HD remaster is frankly a bit of a mess. It crashes regularly under all manner of different circumstances, game will occasionally softlock into a black screen when entering a combat encounter, character models have blacked out during cutscenes (which is kinda funny but it kills the gravitas of a scene quite dead), and FMVs will occasionally just green screen, forcing me to reboot the game and endure a whole chunk of gameplay/cutscenes before getting back to the bit I need to see.

While the problems do not impede the totality of the experience from being enjoyable - and of course some of these problems can be fixed with end user tinkering I don't need to be told about this - these are issues that presented themselves across three different devices (one of them the Steam Deck) and feels a little unacceptable for the product out of the box, especially as compared to memories of playing this game on the PS2 where obviously there was no such performance hiccups, and of course some of these crashes can occur at extremely inopportune moments. There are some other issues as well, which may or may not matter to you depending on how much you care about fidelity to the original product - this game could be said to be more of a reconstruction than a remaster of the game since a lot of the original game data was lost by the devs, and so it doesn't quite ***look right***. These are differences that are ultimately minor and won't matter to the vast majority of players unless you played the PS2 original or you care about authenticity with your experience to the highest degree, but if they matter to you they'll matter a lot.

The games themselves? Excellent JRPGs, of course, and I don't feel obliged to elucidate on their qualities and flaws in here given how much has already been written about them - they peak at phenomenal while occasionally cratering to tedious, but overall I wholeheartedly recommend experiencing them if you are a fan of the JRPG genre or the Final Fantasy franchise in specific, but I would not rate this particular port as the must-go method of doing so, even with fixes and mods applied.

I also think having cheats from the start of the game is a bit of a downer for me. I liked playing and unlocking them, but having all the items and unlimited Gil right off the bat. My biggest issue might be the AI doing auto-battle. It just uses standard attacks and doesn't do much else.
Despite being a Remaster, this keeps a forced 30fps cap that is not removable with mods. The framerate cap also does not have correct frame pacing, both in gameplay and in cutscenes.

I love and adore X and X2, unfortunately on Steam the games don't work. Every cutscene is just a screen colored green and X2 crashes every five minutes. A fan made 4 gigpatch fixes the color green, but not the crashes. PLEASE BUY ON OTHER SYSTEMS OR EMULATE.

I'll start by saying I loved playing X as a kid, and the nostalgia potential was too strong not to pick this up on Steam. Unfortunately, while the nostalgia held up, the port did not. X crashed on me quite often on Steam Deck, so I saved frequently. Eventually, I found that I could not enter a particular building to pick up Wakka's celestial weapon without the game crashing every single time. So, I loaded up my cloud save on my PC, entered just fine, and I continued playing on my Steam Deck. Well, eventually the game wouldn't boot and I received notices that something was wrong with the game files. I validated, and no problems were detected. Huh, odd. Not one day later and my Deck's NVMe, the one the game was played on, died. Whether the game was at fault, I cannot say. I can say that my cloud saves were corrupted and I lost all my 70+ hours of progress. So, there's that.

In all, love X to pieces. I just wish the port were more stable on Deck. As for X-2, some people love it. I'm not one of them, but I can see the appeal.

I will get absolute hate for this review but this is by far one of the worst starts to not only a JRPG but any RPG I have ever played. The characters are bland (MC with Daddy issue and another that falls in love with him within 10 seconds). To top it off the expose of characters is all over the place due to an absolutely butchered localization. I am sure this game was probably somewhat fun when it came out but the dialogue between the characters is borderline cringe and nothing about this game holds up or is a good first time playthrough. This game is recommended by troves of people with nostalgia goggles who do not realize how truly awful this game is for anyone who didn't grow up playing it.

The only possible explanation for a port THIS bad is that they kidnapped a drifter, forced him to port the entire project solo while administering random electric shocks amidst sleep deprivation, immediately pushed it to market, then killed the drifter to cover their tracks. Cutscenes are green-scened, random crashes every 10m or so, occasionally black-screening during scene transitions requiring a reset ... Jesus H. Yevon. On a minor note, good luck figuring out how to use the Boosters, because absolutely nothing in the game or Store page will tell you (it's F1-F5 on the keyboard).

I mean, I'm still gonna play it because I got it 60% off and I'm a sucker for nostalgia, but I refuse to enjoy it. That'll teach 'em. I am very smart.

For the love of god, why did the remaster not include a way to skip the literal hours of cut scenes in this game. And before you say you can... you can only skip the pre-rendered cut scenes all the in-engine cut scenes cannot be skipped. which totals literal hours.... I want FF not a fucking movie.

I wasn't digging it very much in the first 45 minutes of gameplay.  I heard positive things about the game so I thought I'd check it out.  I did enjoy the combat elements -- much better than other older games in the genre.  It was cool with the various QTE elements and it was pretty fast paced which I enjoyed.  I wish they'd get better English voice actors -- man they're really bad at times.  My biggest reason for the 'No Recommendation' is the game is unstable and crashes  -- which is insanely frustrating for a game that requires manual save points and doesn't autosave.  Mandatory unskippable cutscenes are also a huge turnoff.  I grew up on FF6 and FF7, but never tried FFX. I think I'll stick with the ones I know.  I really don't have any desire to keep playing with what I've currently seen and with the crashes.
